Literature Review: The resolution of inflammation is a critical biological process that ensures the return to homeostasis following an inflammatory response. This process is actively mediated by a variety of endogenous molecules, including specialized pro-resolving lipid mediators (SPMs) and peptides such as Annexin A1. The therapeutic potential of these molecules has garnered significant attention, offering a novel approach to managing chronic inflammatory diseases, which are often complicated by comorbidities and inadequately addressed by current pharmacological interventions. This literature review explores the role of Annexin A1 and SPMs in the resolution of inflammation and their potential as therapeutic targets for innovative treatment strategies. Annexin A1, a glucocorticoid-regulated protein, plays a pivotal role in the resolution of inflammation by modulating leukocyte trafficking and promoting the clearance of apoptotic cells. Its anti-inflammatory and pro-resolving actions have been demonstrated in various models of inflammatory diseases, highlighting its potential as a therapeutic agent. Similarly, SPMs, including lipoxins, resolvins, protectins, and maresins, are bioactive lipid mediators derived from omega-3 and omega-6 polyunsaturated fatty acids. These mediators actively promote the resolution of inflammation by reducing leukocyte infiltration, enhancing macrophage phagocytosis, and stimulating tissue repair. The therapeutic innovation lies in the ability to augment the expression or function of these pro-resolving pathways or to mimic their actions with novel targeted molecules. Such strategies not only address the primary cause of inflammatory diseases but also manage their comorbidities, ultimately improving patient quality of life. The implementation of resolution pharmacology represents a paradigm shift in the management of inflammatory conditions, harnessing the whole physiology of inflammation to achieve a marked change in clinical outcomes. This approach offers a promising avenue for the development of new therapies that are more effective and have fewer side effects than current treatments. By focusing on the biology of the resolution of inflammation, researchers can uncover novel therapeutic targets and develop innovative treatments that improve the management of chronic inflammatory diseases and their associated comorbidities.
